summary: A satirical critique of geocentric beliefs and biblical literalism, using exaggerated characters and flawed logic for comedic effect.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an elderly man with a long white beard and hair, wearing a light-colored shirt, seated in a cozy living room. The room is warmly lit by a lamp on a side table, with vertical blinds covering a window in the background. A framed picture hangs on the wall, and a wooden cabinet with glass doors is visible. The man appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. At one point, text appears at the bottom of the screen, reading "MegaSage007 -- Golden Crocoduck nominee," indicating that the man may be discussing or promoting something related to this title. The camera remains focused on the man, capturing his expressions and movements as he continues to speak. The overall atmosphere is calm and intimate, with the man's presence dominating the scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with two male speakers, one welcoming the other to a video message directed towards the atheist movement. The speaker, with a passionate tone, declares their intent to debunk them. He then poses a rhetorical question about the lack of severe weather on Earth, implying the Earth is not in motion, and emphasizing the concept of perception, like the old-fashioned wind-up clock. The second speaker notes that "Colonel Sanders is right." The first then continues about the Earth standing still and the universe spinning around us.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of an elderly man with a long white beard, wearing a light-colored robe, seated in a room with vertical blinds and a framed picture on the wall. The scene transitions to a detailed black-and-white illustration of a circular diagram with concentric circles and various symbols, including the names of celestial bodies such as 'MARTIS,' 'SOLIS,' 'VENERIS,' 'MERCVRII,' and 'LUNA,' suggesting a focus on astronomy or astrology. The video then shifts to a painting depicting a historical scene with four individuals, including a man in a dark robe standing and three seated figures, one of whom is a nun, in a room with a table covered in a red cloth. The narrative continues with two elderly men with long white beards, one wearing a striped shirt and the other a brown shirt, standing in front of a couch with a cityscape painting in the background. The man in the brown shirt is reading from a book, while the other man gestures with his hands, indicating a discussion or explanation. The video concludes with a close-up of the man in the striped shirt, who appears to be speaking, with the cityscape painting still visible in the background, maintaining a consistent indoor setting throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker arguing that the Bible states the earth is fixed. He then reads from a bible verse, asserting that "the world also is established, that it cannot be moved." The same speaker then refers to an individual making a list and claims Biblical scholars believed in a fixed Earth. Following this, he asks if the former individual is simply "one man crying in the wilderness." He then remarks that there appear to be two individuals now. He concludes the first section by claiming belief in geocentric worlds is held by many creationists. A quick cut ensues, with the same male speaker remarking on a second person who believes they can prove this with physics.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of Earth from space, accompanied by the text "We are not going to just ASSUME they know what they are talking about..." in yellow font, suggesting skepticism about the information being presented. The text "ferniboy100 -- Golden Crocoduck nominee" appears at the bottom, indicating a nomination for a video or content creator. The scene transitions to an indoor setting where a man in a yellow shirt is seated at a desk with various electronic equipment, including a computer monitor displaying graphs and data, suggesting a technical or scientific environment. The next scene shows another man in a white shirt sitting in a vehicle, possibly a van, with electronic equipment visible in the background, indicating a mobile setup. The video then shifts to an outdoor scene featuring a large telescope on a platform, with a person standing next to it, highlighting the scale and complexity of the equipment. The final scene depicts a white truck with a trailer, equipped with antennas and other equipment, parked in an open field under a cloudy sky, suggesting a remote or field research location. The video combines elements of space, technology, and scientific exploration, emphasizing the importance of verification and the diverse settings in which scientific work is conducted.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with one male speaker introducing a video about whether the Earth can spin or not, setting a curious tone. Another male speaker with a slightly skeptical tone replies enthusiastically, calling it an "experiment". The first speaker returns, becoming more critical as he describes the experiment being done, implying its simplicity and limited scope. The audio then shifts to include a brief sound of someone blowing air quickly, adding a humorous or absurd element.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a hand holding a remote control, with a small helicopter on a moving platform in the background. The text "Watch closely what happens when it launches from a moving object" appears on the screen, setting the stage for an experiment. The scene transitions to a black screen with white text explaining that the helicopter takes off while the carrier vehicle continues on its way. The next scene shows a person measuring the distance between the helicopter and the moving platform, emphasizing the experiment's setup. The video then returns to the helicopter on the platform, with the text "Takeoff" displayed, as the helicopter launches into the air. The helicopter is shown in mid-air, with the text "Takeoff" still visible, highlighting the moment of launch. The video then transitions to a black screen with white text explaining that the helicopter does not maintain the same speed as the truck, emphasizing the difference in motion. The final scene shows a truck moving at a low speed, with the text "THIS FACT IS SEEN AT EVEN LESS THAN 10 MILES PER HOUR," reinforcing the experiment's findings. The video concludes with a black screen displaying white text that reads, "It does NOT keep moving at the same speed as the truck, If it DID then the earth very well COULD be spinning- but it lags WAY behind as soon as it's airborne !!!" This text emphasizes the key takeaway from the experiment, highlighting the difference in motion between the helicopter and the truck.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker discussing how "Ferny boy invested about a hundred bucks" in a toy truck and remote-controlled helicopter. He speaks in a calm, explanatory tone, outlining a principle related to the Earth's rotation and jumping. He explains that if the Earth were spinning rapidly, jumping would result in being left behind or shot backward. Transitioning to a demonstration, he describes how the vehicle keeps moving, but the helicopter doesn't move with it as it rises.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man driving a dark-colored SUV, wearing a blue shirt, with trees in the background. The scene transitions to a train moving along a track in a desert-like environment, with people hanging out of the windows and one person jumping off the train onto the ground. The man who jumped off the train is then seen standing in the desert, picking up a bag and a black cat. He is wearing a light blue shirt and beige pants. The video concludes with the man standing in the desert, speaking to the camera, with the vast sandy landscape and clear blue sky in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker questioning why David Adams performed a dramatic roll in the sand after jumping from a train, suggesting he was "just showing off." Following this commentary, the audio transitions to the sound of a train in motion. A different male speaker, seemingly having just jumped from a train, states he doesn't recommend jumping off trains and feels he might have injured his collarbone. The clip concludes with his repeated advice against the practice.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing in a vast desert landscape, wearing a light blue shirt and looking down, possibly at something on the ground. The scene transitions to a moving vehicle, a dark-colored pickup truck, with a man in a blue shirt driving it. The truck is surrounded by trees, indicating a change in location from the desert to a more forested area. The video then shifts to a high-speed train, white with blue stripes, moving swiftly along a track. The train is filled with passengers, visible through the windows, and the platform is visible on the side, suggesting a bustling station environment. The video captures the dynamic movement of the train, emphasizing its speed and the busy atmosphere of the station.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker who sarcastically discusses a "Ferny boy" and his theory that objects don't have inertia. The speaker suggests that according to this theory, there would be no risk in jumping off moving vehicles, and even recommends that Ferny boy test his theory on a speeding train. Throughout the clip, there is background noise of a train passing.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blurry image of a train in motion, with passengers visible through the windows. The scene transitions to a clear image of a historical figure, likely a scientist, with a quote below him in blue text. The quote reads, "Every object persists in its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless it is compelled to change that state by forces impressed on it." This quote is a paraphrase of Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the Law of Inertia. The background is plain white, emphasizing the figure and the quote. The video maintains this image for several frames, focusing on the historical figure and the quote, without any additional visual changes or transitions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker, delivering information in an articulate, somewhat mocking tone. He references Isaac Newton's laws of motion, then sarcastically asks "Well, what does Isaac Newton know?". He mentions "Fernieboy", then continues discussing the concept with rhetorical questions. The tone shifts to become more agreeable as he finishes with a simple "Good point." There are no discernible background sounds or music in the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white image of a man with a long beard and hair, wearing a white shirt, against a dark background. Overlaid on the image is a quote from Ecclesiastes 1:5, discussing the sun's daily cycle, followed by a quote from Newton's laws of motion, explaining the persistence of an object's state of rest or uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force. The scene transitions to a black background with white text, displaying more biblical verses from Psalms 93:1 and 1 Chronicles 16:30, emphasizing the stability of the world and the fear of God. The text "ferniboy100 -- Golden Crocoduck nominee" appears at the bottom of each frame, indicating the creator or contributor of the video. The video then shifts to a close-up of the same man, with the text "So who are you going to believe?" overlaid, prompting viewers to consider their beliefs. The video concludes with the man's image and the same text, reinforcing the question posed to the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a character named "Ferney Boy," likening him to "scary Colonel Sanders," and noting that his views are based on "the word of God" rather than physics. He expresses doubt about Ferney Boy's grasp of basic physics, speculating that he might be a parody. This male speaker has a critical tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person with a white beard and wild hair, wearing a white shirt, against a dark background. Text on the right side of the frame reads, "People like this? Or the creator himself?" (suggesting a humorous or self-referential tone). Below, additional text states, "fernieboy100 -- Golden Crocoduck nominee," indicating a nomination for a humorous award. The scene transitions to a man in a blue shirt standing in a room with green walls, gesturing with his hands as if explaining something. The room features a window with potted plants on the sill and a black and white piece of furniture. The man continues to gesture and speak, with a green overlay effect appearing on his head in one frame, adding a playful or surreal element. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's expressive gestures and speech, with the background elements remaining unchanged throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker introducing a topic, speaking in a clear tone, and mentions that someone's "IQ is off the charts." Next, the sound of machinery running in the background is audible. Another male speaker begins discussing the Earth's spin, mentioning "Coriolis forces" and "gravity," speaking somewhat hesitantly. There's a brief sound of gears grinding, indicating difficulty thinking. The speaker then uses the metaphor of magnets to explain why the sun affects the Earth's spin, acknowledging, "The sun will make the Earth spin around." The machinery sound continues in the background. The speaker transitions to discussing geocentrism, noting that it "requires a continuous miracle." He explains his reasoning, suggesting that the sun orbiting the Earth would eventually "get out of balance" and switch places. Finally, a response, "No it's not gonna go out of balance," is spoken by the first male speaker in a slightly sarcastic tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a blue shirt standing in a room with green walls, gesturing as he speaks. The scene transitions to a black screen with two yellow circles, one larger than the other, representing the Sun and Earth. The next frame shows a bright yellow circle with a red dot, labeled "Solar System Barycenter / SSB," indicating the center of mass of the solar system. The video then shifts to a nighttime shot of a man in a white shirt and green shorts performing a hammer throw in a stadium, with the NBC Olympics logo visible. The man spins and releases the hammer, which flies through the air. The scene changes to a daytime shot of another man in a white shirt and blue pants, also performing a hammer throw in a stadium, with a scoreboard displaying "LATVIA" and "81.80." The video concludes with the man walking away from the throwing area, with the scoreboard still visible in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining how two large bodies in space orbit each other, emphasizing that they both orbit a common point called the barycenter. His tone is factual and instructive. He uses the examples of our solar system and a hammer thrower to illustrate the concept. A different male speaker interjects with a condescending tone, saying he learned this in seventh grade. The first speaker continues, implying that the previous speaker should have grasped the concept before discussing dinosaur eggs.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man wearing a blue shirt standing in a room with green walls. He appears to be speaking or gesturing, with a window and potted plants visible in the background. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a black Holy Bible with gold lettering and a cross on the cover, placed against a white background. The Bible is shown from different angles, emphasizing its cover and spine, which also features gold lettering. The video maintains a focus on the Holy Bible, highlighting its design and details without any additional context or movement.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker who asserts that geocentrists are at least honest in their interpretation of the Bible, which he claims explicitly states that the Earth is at the center of the universe and does not move. He then argues that only after science disproved this notion, the Bible was reinterpreted, a common occurrence when science contradicts it. His tone is conversational and slightly opinionated.
